content: The "American Workforce Improvement and Jobs Protection Act" exempts aliens with a master's or higher degree from numerical limitations on H-1B nonimmigrants. The "American Workforce Improvement and Jobs Protection Act" exempts aliens with a master's or higher degree from numerical limitations on H-1B nonimmigrants. SEC. 3. MAKING PERMANENT CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS AND AUTHORITIES WITH RESPECT TO H-1B NONIMMIGRANTS. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change attestation requirements and fees, as well as repeal Department of Labor investigative authorities. The effective dates for these changes are specified. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change attestation requirements and fees, as well as repeal Department of Labor investigative authorities. The effective dates for these changes are specified: the fee amendment applies to petitions filed 30 days after enactment, and the investigative authority repeal takes effect immediately. SEC. 4. FRAUD PREVENTION AND DETECTION FEE. The Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of State are authorized to impose fraud prevention and detection fees on employers filing petitions for certain nonimmigrant statuses and on aliens applying for visas for admission to the United States. The H-1B and L Fraud Prevention and Detection Account is established with a fee of $500 for principal aliens under certain petitions. Fees collected will be deposited in the Treasury as per section 286(v) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Fees collected under section 214(c)(12) will be deposited into the H-1B and L Fraud Prevention and Detection Account. One-third of these funds will be available to the Secretary of State for programs at U.S. embassies to combat fraud by visa applicants. One-third of the fees collected under section 214(c)(12) will be deposited into the H-1B and L Fraud Prevention and Detection Account. This amount will be available to the Secretary of Homeland Security to prevent and detect fraud, as well as assist in carrying out fraud prevention and detection programs and activities. The Secretary of Homeland Security will receive funds for fraud prevention programs related to nonimmigrant status petitions. The Secretary of Labor will also receive funds for enforcement programs. Consultation between the Secretaries of State, Homeland Security, and Labor is required for fund usage. The amendments made by this section require consultation between the Secretaries of State, Homeland Security, and Labor for the use of funds in the H-1B and L Fraud Prevention and Detection Account. The effective date of these amendments is the date of the enactment of the Act, with fees applying to petitions and visa applications filed 90 days after enactment. SEC. 5. Ensuring integrity of visas for intracompany transferees. The nonimmigrant L-1 visa category is amended to restrict aliens with specialized knowledge from being stationed primarily at a worksite of an employer other than the petitioning employer or its affiliate. This is to prevent the alien from being controlled and supervised by the unaffiliated employer or used solely for labor provision rather than for a product or service. The amendment restricts aliens with specialized knowledge from working primarily at a worksite of an employer other than the petitioning employer or its affiliate. It also requires prior continuous employment for certain intracompany transferees. The amendment applies to petitions filed on or after the effective date of this section. The Secretary of Homeland Security will maintain statistics on petitions filed for nonimmigrants with specialized knowledge, including those working primarily at offsite locations. These statistics will apply to petitions filed on or after the effective date of this section. The section and its amendments will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act.
